title: Challenges of an Innovation Ecosystem in Austria

author: Thomas Wallner, Upper Austria University of Applied Sciences

My name is Thomas Viner.
I'm a professor of system thinking and supply chain management at the Upper Austrian University of Applied Sciences in Inch Tire in Austria, and we actually.
Have a master program called Supply Chain Management, where Innovation is an integral topic.

We have this integrated in courses like entrepreneurship and digital products and markets and we have also developed a very specific course format called KOI which stands for creativity, decision-making and realization which makes sure that we have an innovative problem solving in management approaches.
I'm also doing some research and innovation topics and then hosting a panel discussion series.
On process innovation in Austria, so I'm talking with many people about these things and about innovation and tell you can tell you everybody in Austria.

And.
How critical it was for future successes.

And has moved up 7 notches since 2006, so Australia is actually among the catching up countries is actually one of those on the verge of becoming a front runner.
A so called innovation leader so you may ask me well.
What is you talking about when it was talking?
My topic is challenges to the innovation ecosystem in Austria.
Um?
Well.
It's not that simple.
I think we do have quite some imbalances in the innovation ecosystem in Austria.
Let's investigate this a little bit.
This is the so-called innovation map in Austria.
This is actually the Upper Austrian province and what you can see here.
All kinds of institutions and organizations fostering supporting innovation activities.
When I looked at the details behind this map, what immediately struck my mind that was the fact that the notion of innovation was very much limited to product innovation and technology.

Sometimes with a special focus on certain technologies like Mechatronics and things like that, as you can see this leaflet is Co published by the Federal Ministry of Traffic and Innovation and Technology, so we do have an innovation ministry in Austria.
Let's have a look how they.
Actually addressing the issue, and again, you can see all kinds of technology, technology, technology, technology.
So in the topics covered and the programs launched.
And if you go to human resources.
Below then you find again and then again into innovation generation, which actually sounded pretty promising to me.
Again, you have a program supporting, for example, young women.
So to to make technology accessible to them, so I'm not against this kind of programs.
Don't let me be misunderstood, but innovation must be more than that, especially when it comes to young people, and especially if you ask me in Austria.
So from my point of view, this is a pretty limited view.
So where does this come from?
This view that innovation was something which happens behind closed doors in the cane aren T Department in secret laboratories or secluded circles.
Where does this view come from that our innovation is something which were only a chosen few, can take part and launch a couple of products and make lots of money.
Will in Austria public innovation activities.
Driven by pressure groups out of the economic sector like Chamber of Commerce and Federal Federation of Austrian Industries.
In other organizations related to them.
So it's not really surprised that also is putting lots of money into company research projects.
We do have the highest share on government aid of innovation projects in Europe.
Almost 1% of GDP goes to the public innovation promotion programs.
The lion's share of this.
Three times as much as in Germany goes into corporate R&D projects.

ROI is always related to time, of course, so.

This is one of the imbalances I wanted to point out what I mentioned in the beginning so, but how about the Austrian society as a whole is also as a society.
As a national community innovative.
Let us have a look at another innovation index.

It's the so called in overtones indikator Deutschland and this is an extensive study funded by the Federation of German Industries and the Deutsche Telekom Foundation, and it's based on 180 indicators, including soft indicators, which is important from my point of view.
And here the Austrian success story sort of looks a little bit quite different.
It doesn't have these happy ending, which is usually broadcast it in the official statement.
Austria is actually ranked.
14 and in the innovation climate, which you can see here, we are ranked last out of 70 nations.
Well, we have to be aware this not the Europeans is not European Community.
We do have a different sample.
These are the 17 most developed countries in a global perspective.
So this is what the closer look.
I think the category social societal innovation climate is composed of.
The following sub indicators.
Attitude charts change consisting of attitude towards.
Entrepreneurial risk taking openness and tolerance and attitude towards women's employment.

The second indicator includes is called attitude towards science and technology and this includes interest in science, trust in scientists and organizations doing research and appreciation of opportunities and risks coming from scientific research and the third indicator is relates to social commitment in each.
In each of these three indicators.

Australia shrink last so Austrian society doesn't really seem to be innovation friendly and embracing change and these findings become even more disturbing when you look at the growing importance of process innovation and the potential which lies in the re framing of business model models and rethinking entire supply chains.
Because focusing inthis aspects means that you that you have to include larger portions, larger sections of the company.
Often crossing departmental boundaries and also going to the outside world as well here.
Innovative culture of the entire organization and or of society as such becomes the fertile ground for innovation, progress and substantial change.
If also in politics were genuinely interested in this.
Aspect of innovation.
This finding could mean a clear mandate to take action.
So had let's have a look at Austrian politics.
How about Austin politics?
Are they innovative?
In terms of political agility and innovativeness.
Also appears awkwardly paralyzed.
Let me underpin this with findings of an expert in Austrian politics.
It's Professor Anton Pelinka.
He's the doyen of Austrian politician political scientists.
In a recent speech about the paralyzed Republic, held on a conference on the state of Politics in Austria.
Polly Pelinka delivered a pretty accurate assessment of the political situation in Austria.
Austrian politics have become defensive.
the Republic itself has become structural conservative and the last great effort was the accession to the European Community.
Since then, the big nothing vision.
The concepts of the future are not in demand.
The Austrian educational system, especially the Austrian educational system, is affected by that compared to our net national wealth.
Austrian education output has to be ranked ranked at the very bottom of the list.
This is not my words.
These are the words of Mr.
Professor pillinger.
Excuse me as you may have.
Heard Austrias University at dramatically underfunded.
The situation is so desperate that even the Deans of the Aurora University, according to arms, they actually lining up with the students and and organizing protests.
So this is quite a sort of visa.
If you look at the history of student protests in the recent decades, it always always was against University establishment.
Now they're lining up.
According to Professor Pinker, we must not expect the political sector to set any impulses.
This have to come from the civil society.
So we come to the same conclusion.
I come from very different.
Pie, very different path.
But in the end we come to the same conclusion.
Yeah we have.
So what do we have to do?
What we have to do?
Let me first lighten up this a little bit grim look on the Austrian situation.
It's not all that bad.
You know.
Of course there is a lively scene of all kinds of young dynamic organizations and quite a few people off the mainstream.
And of course there are new structures developed, many of them in some kind of a grassroots movement in the they do need our attention.
They really deserve our support in our energy, which leads directly to the challenges.
Of the innovation ecosystem in Austria.
The first challenge is we have to develop the Austrian culture thoughts.

Open this tolerance and attitude towards innovation and change to appreciate that this involves strengthening of these mentioned organizations initiatives and bring innovation and societal change more and more into the public discussion into the entire Internet educational system into the entire educational system and into the rural communities.
That's where the hands Hinterseer fence live, you know.
And we do have lots of them here there.
Improvement comes in handy, so we do need more creative people than hunting into their fence.
Here in Australia, the second challenge is to develop the entire educational system with a special focus on the universities.
According to the already mentioned German innovate innovations indicator, only 19% of the age bracket between 25 and 39 years old is highly qualified in Austria compared to average.
Again, the 77 countries 38% so this results in a critical sort shortage of highly skilled workforce which is even aggravated by Austria's restricted immigration policy.

Austin companies were pretty quick in going to new emerging markets, for example in Central Eastern Europe and at the same time they were fiercely protecting our labor market against people coming from from the same regions so.
We and this is even an amplified by the fact that we do have the lowest share of highly educated people among immigrants, which means we don't let them in.
And those we let in.
They are not highly qualified and the third challenge is to enhance the financial preconditions for innovation.
When it comes to Accessibility of bank loans and startup financing.
In these categories, Austria thank 14th out of 17 and probably.
This position has even worsened during the economic crisis, so we have a lot to do.
Anna Steven already emphasized it's the doing, isn't it?
It's not the talking is not the complaining.
It's not the blaming we have to do it, so maybe we just have to start an equal movement in Austria, isn't it?
Thank you very much.
